Ratings.comment: This guy just rambles on constantly each lecture, flying through the slides and not giving you enough time to write the terms down, not to mention there's like 10 new terms on each slide that he doesn't bother explaining.  There's only 3 grades (midterm, final, and an essay) and the tests DO NOT reflect the content we learned in class.

The professor himself is amazing, he is very kind and dedicated to his subject. I took this class for a GE requirement, and I don't think this was the class for me. The only grades that go in are a midterm, final, and research paper. I was frequently very stressed about this class.

Dr. Mckee is so set in his ways and refuses to think about how that affects his students. Your grade is based on 3 exams composed of intentional trick questions. Attendance is optional but if you don't go you won't pass. His lectures are disorganized, he just points at things, says the name, and doesn't answer questions. He is also downright rude.

Your grade depends on three exams.  Attendance is not mandatory however to do well on exams you have to come to lectures and take notes.  Lectures could be rather disorganized at times and he is not very good with technology.  He even sent our exam to the wrong class once.

Dr. McKee is SO cool. Hes such an interesting person and is just the sweetest guy. He cares about his students so much and has done so much interesting anthropology work throughout his life and has a lot of interesting stories. Also, the subject matter of his class is super interesting. Ill miss having him as a professor a lot.

This class is SO unorganized and hard to take notes for. He just points out things written on his pp, finishes class within 30 minutes, and then just gives 3 exams, and the tests are your only grade. He seems like a nice guy, but a terrible teacher who doesn't seem to ever know the answer to anyone's questions. I've had him twice now, both were bad

One of the best professors Ive had at OSU. Prof. McKee has so many interesting stories from his time in S Africa, which relate to the material. He is quirky, but I enjoyed his jokes. The class was pretty easy with tests being open book. Make sure you take detailed notes as most of the questions were from lecture. Labs are completion which is nice.
The only grades we received were tests and one paper. The professor didn't bother to communicate grades or feedback once we switched to online due to the pandemic in 2020. Lack of understanding.

Definitely go to class. Most of the material on exams is covered in the powerpoint. The powerpoint are not posted online and he doesn't use Carmen. I really like him as a person but not a great professor. He made a gen ed class so much harder than it should have been.

Genuinely one of the kindest people I have ever met. It is very clear he cares about the students in the class, and he enjoys teaching. He puts effort into being interesting and caring to his students, and is one of the most passionate instructors I have had at OSU. A real gen of a professor, I wish I could take him again.

McKee is the best professor I've had at main campus so far in personality. He is hilarious and will always make you laugh in his lectures. His exams are not too bad. They are multiple choice, short answer and essay usually. Just study and you'll be fine.
There are 3 exams for the entire class and a paper for extra credit. Hes super chill but lectures can feel a bit unorganized.
Lectures are very boring and unorganized. Tests were hard but if you study a lot you will pass. No textbook is used in class. He is nice and kinda funny.

Don't take this class. It's 1000x harder than the non-honors version. Professor McKee is extremely unorganized and doesn't even know his own syllabus. Exams are half multiple-choice/half essay and the essay portion is graded very harshly. There are three exams that basically decide your grade. He does not curve. He does not use Carmen.

THIS CLASS IS AWFUL. SO DISORGANIZED, TAKES OFF POINTS FOR ESSAYS ON EXAMS WITHOUT CLARIFICATION OF WHY. HORRIBLY MESSY LECTURES. never been so frustrated in a class. worst teacher I have ever taken at ohio state

The lectures are kind of dry and not the most interesting, however the labs are incredibly easy and there is no homework besides studying and a quick quiz before the labs. Professor McKee is clearly very knowledgeable and tells great stories about his anthropology adventures. The tests are pretty hard and are 67% of your grade.

Dr. McKee tells interesting stories about his experiences in South Africa, and the labs are participation graded and the pre lab quizzes are easy. His lectures are unorganized and hard to take notes on, and exams are over 60% of your grade with extended response questions. I found the exams fairly difficult, and you really have to study hard.

Solid choice if looking to fulfill a natural science GE - especially for people not into the hard sciences. Labs are really easy. Lectures are disorganized and unclear. He is passionate about his work and that shows but does not convey his knowledge effectively. There are three exams which you will need to study for. Will need to work for an A.

You must attend for the lectures in order to pass the exams. If you take good notes from the lectures and go to labs, you'll only need to study for 2-4 hours for the exams and get an A. He makes good jokes and has great stories related to the class from his fieldwork.

Prof. McKee is good. Not the easiest class (gotta work for the A), must attend every lecture because he doesn't put the slides online. Enthusiastic and extremely knowledgable about his coursework. Lot of memorization but it makes sense in the end.

pretty uptight teacher, having a really high skill English comprehension/ using pretty big words seems to threaten her, and she will believe a faulty ai detector and threaten you with reporting when everything was 100% human written. so be sure to dumb your stuff down a bit otherwise you risk being flagged.

Definitely an easy A. Good lectures/slideshows with engaging content, but every assignment was essentially graded for completion with the exception of the labs/projects. Definitely a good class to get you into anthropology, or just to fill a GE requirement.

Easy A. Quizzes are open note. Projects are middle school science level. Prof is kind and lowkey funny. Labs are also middle school level. Only downside is lab reports and weekly reflections; they are both incredibly easy but so boring because they feel like elementary level. Best class to fulfill GE and honors requirements as non science major.

I'm here to make sure she has a 5 out of 5. Took her class in 21Spring, she's still one of my favorite instructors at OSU! You can feel she's super sweet, caring and passionate. Her exams are fair too.

Great professor and a genuinely easy A. Labs were worth small portion of your grade but you get full credit if a reasonable attempt was made. There were 3 exams worth most of your grade that weren't too bad so as long as you passed those you passed the class.

I took ANTHROP 2200 online for my bio credit (not a stem person) I thought the class was super boring but its pretty easy if you are just getting a GE credit. The online labs wernt supported on my laptop so i would fail everyone and I still got an a. If you enjoy learning about evolution you would love this class.

Really cares about the material. Very upbeat and interesting lectures. Makes you work for the grade but is reasonable. I really enjoyed the class. She did very well condensing 15 weeks of material into 6 week summer course. I am actually sad that classes are finished.

This was a great online course! She had a rubric for every assignment and as long as you follow that and put effort into your writing, you'll do fine. The subject was actually really interesting and surprisingly made me want to take more anthropology courses.

Dr. Trask's class is challenging, but engaging. Though the exams test your in-depth knowledge, Unstuck study proved to be a helpful tool for study prep alongside the textbook. Overall, a rewarding experience for anthro enthusiasts.

This professor cares for her students, easy to communicate. This course has weekly discussion post watch films, discuss it, respond to 2 peers. Written mid-term in-class, & final written online, study guide for both, there is also a group presentation (12 min minimum), and infographic at the end. There is a book, but don't need it to pass the class

This Professor is one you will remember, she is amazing and really cares. This class contains weekly discussion post watch films, discuss it, respond to 2 peers. Written mid-term in-class, a final written online, study guide for both, there also is a 12-page paper at the end of the class. The class isn't difficult if you try and complete the work.

She truly cares about her students welling being, wants everyone to succeed. Class contains weekly discussion post watch films, discuss it, respond to 2 peers. Multiple-choice mid-term in-class, a final multiple-choice online, study guide for both. Offers EX when students didn't go to class. Easy to reach through email and office hours

Dr. Trask is extremely knowledgeable and passionate in her lectures. She keeps the classroom interested and engaged due to this, and I never once felt afraid to ask for help. I do agree with other reviewers, though, because I could study for the midterm/final for hours and hours and still do poorly.

As an engineer I took this class as a GE like most people. Lexines appreciation for the subject shows, as she has a knowledge that is shocking in its array and depth. 

The class is very managable, ~biweekly homework which you should get a 100 with marginal effort. Exams are the lecture, go to class and it is not hard to get a pleasing grade.

Her class is very manageable and she also makes it very interesting. You only have one midterm and one final and the most amount of homework you get is two discussion posts a week. I would say study study study for the big tests because it may seem like you know enough about the class until you see your score lol.

I would not take a class with Dr. Trask again. Lots of readings and she speaks very slowly during lectures to the point that it's difficult to follow. Grades participation during class but only calls on a couple of people. She was very off putting and seemed like she didn't want to be there or interact with most students.

You can tell that she is very passionate about what she teaches and keeps you very interested in the course material. She can be a tough grader sometimes, but she does give a 2 day grace period on assignments if you really need it. Overall, if you show up to class everyday and do what she asks of you, it isn't hard to get an A in this course.

Dr. Trask is my favorite professor or teacher I've ever had. She always considers the student's mental health and is very lenient on deadlines. She deeply cares about all her students and genuinely wants them to succeed in class and life. The course can be challenging for someone new to Anthropology, but she will always take the extra time to help.
If you try to care about the material, you'll find that it is actually pretty interesting. I wouldn't expect to fall asleep in class and wake up with an A though.

Dr. Trask is a very intelligent person. I find that her lectures are stimulating and enjoyable, but she does require a lot of reading for this class specifically. All her courses have been a lot of work and required extensive studying and required attendance. I do not love the way she makes exams, but going to lectures helps you on the tests.

Dr. Trask is incredibly intelligent and knowledgeable. You can tell she is passionate about the topics she teaches. Takes attendance every lecture. Weekly homework and some discussions, but nothing difficult. The midterm is hard. The questions are very specific. Luckily there are a lot of other assignments to help boost grade.

Dr. Trask is super intelligent and knowledgable in her field and did an amazing job with the new 2210 class introduced to satisfy the GE credit. She was super helpful, always provided valuable advice, and made the class easy with active participation and listening. Would highly recommend her for Anthro2210!

as a nonanthropology major I was intimidated and thought I would do badly, but the requirements for assignments and exams are clear. I did much better than I was expecting. We read 2 novels for the class and I really enjoyed them. Definitely go to class because the discussion information is vital for exams. She is very willing to help her students

I've had Dr. Trask for about three classes now at Ohio State and she is absolutely my favorite professor I've had. She is passionate about her course material and presents the information in lectures that I find easy to follow. She is lenient with late work and provides a 48-hour grace on most assignments. I would recommend any course with her.

Dr. Trask is one of my favorite professors ever.  She is very knowledgeable about what she is teaching and creates lectures that are easy to follow and engage.  There are weekly reading assignments, but nothing is too lengthy.  You are expected two write two reflection papers, along with create and respond to weekly discussion posts.

This class was exceptionally difficult with all her questions being extremally specific and niche. I was one of the only people who did not bomb the midterms (average ~ 60%) and it took was rewatching and retaking notes for all her lectures for full days on end to get an A on them. Great prof if you love anthro, run if you don't.

Dr. Trask is very thorough and seems like a sweet woman, but I would not take her class again due to how difficult she made it. Everyone bombed the midterm due to how niche the questions were. Friends that took this class from other profs said it was super easy, but that wasn't the case here. I'd recommend a different professor if you can.

She is seriously amazing and changed my life. So passionate about meaningful subjects. Random but relevant tangents make it so interesting. Very knowledgable and grounded. Don't worry about doing bad, if you read the texts and participate you're in the clear. She's lenient with late work and understands we are human beings. Truly enlightening prof
Very nice and relaxed 11/10
Such a sweet lady and tries to make lectures interesting
I took both the lecture and the lab, it was my favorite class this semester. Graver is super kind and funny. She is super understanding and easy it is easy to ask her for help. 10/10 Recommend!!!

Took Professor Graver for both Forensic Anthropology and the Lab class. Even if you don't have any background in Anthropology, Professor Graver's knowledge and experience with the subject help make the class easy to understand. As long as you attend class regularly, you should be able to have a successful semester.

This is my third class with Professor Graver. I recommend her classes to most people I know in person. The classes are fairly straightforward. Show up, take notes and do the assignment, there's no tests in the lab classes and she's conscientious of student's time in all her classes.

attendance is only mandatory if you were in the lab. she was very carin, understanding, and nice especially when I came to grading. She has a cute little personality and you could tell she likes what she does.

Prof. Graver is an amazing professor to have (btw I'm writing this from Chabot). Her class is pretty easy because we have to pay attention to lectures which are entertaining because it's not a typical boring lecture and she talks about herself in them. Although she doesn't assign homework, we always have hands-on classwork to do at least each week.

The class was interesting and taught a lot of interesting details regarding anthropology. She wasn't strict or harsh she just taught well and gave helpful assignments and tests. A nice and easygoing professor with a likable personality.

Super nice and funny- loved her! Made the class interesting even when there were more boring topics like naming bones. Final project you get to do anything you want that's about the class which was cool. Easy class, easy assignments. It was like a nice break taking this class. Make sure to study for the bone tests tho! Def would retake her

Love Professor Graver most sweetest person ever!  Her class is really fun and interesting! We only did classwork no homework. She is really passionate about what she teaches. Classwork is pretty easy too! I wish she was my professor for all my classes. DEFINITELY recommend taking her class!

Professor Graver's anthro class is super chill and interesting. She gives great lectures and is obviously passionate about the material. The grade was based on quizzes (based on the lectures), the final (an "unessay", I did a presentation), and a couple other scattered assignments on the material. An A is very manageable. She is witty and cute.

I love Ms. Graver, a really down-to-earth teacher. She made me watch Game of Thrones and we share multiple interests in shows. She is a real sweetheart, and wish she was not my teacher, more so I wish I would have met her around the same age because she is quite stunning as well. For sure take her class at Chabot College in Hayward.

She's definitely one of the best teachers I've ever had. Super caring, understanding, and respectful. She always lets you make up work and helps if you don't understand something. Very little hw or quizzes, mainly lectures and classwork. Super fun to talk to about any topic. Highly rec taking ANY of her classes.

I took Professor Graver at Chabot College in Hayward California, she is truly a amazing professor, her class is easy and its a super interesting class. She even took us on a Feld trip for a lesson, she's a amazing and super chill professor.

She teaches Biological Anthropology and Forensic Anthropology at Chabot College, in Hayward, CA. I have taken both her Bio Anth course and her Forensic Anth course as well as her corresponding labs. She is by far the best professor I have ever had at Chabot. She is very textbook heavy in her Bio Anth course but not so much in Forensic Anth.

This class was not the worst. Her forensic anthropology class and great and enjoyable. The only part that was difficult were the exams. The first half of the semester would be exams then switched us over to assignemnt which were very easy. If you recieve bad test scores, dont worry about it. Just do the exams and the final project and youll pass.

Professor Sally is an Anthropology teacher at Chabot College! It wasnt ANTHR200 - at Chabot it was Anthro13/13L She is so excited about her lectures and i love her humor! Shes very helpful when it comes down to questions and she can definitely sometimes gives you a way to make up your assignments!

I took her anthro lab class this summer online at Chabot and shes the best! She makes her lectures interesting, homework/labs are reasonable and easy. No exams for the lab class so you have to do well on hw/labs. Available through email if you need help. Very sweet person! As long as you dont procrastinate, this class should be a breeze.

Hands down one of the best professor at Chabot College! She is also beautiful and has a very sweet voice. She does pretty excellent job in everything. Gives challenging tests which are all covered in her lectures. I got some low and high scores and my grade was -B then I took the extra credit she offered and my grade went -B to A. Shes the best!

Shes a very sweet anthro lab instructor at Chabot College! The exams were very challenging and covers around 4 chapters. Need to pay attention to your regular anthro 1 course in order to do good on exams. The slides she uses arent very helpful and goes through them very fast. She brings food often, no hw, helps w questions passed with an easy A!

This class was an amazing experience, I recommend it if anyone wants to just learn about food. There are some textbooks and light reading involved to understand discussions in class or tests. If you want a class that is engaging and the professor to crack some jokes (that are funny), then this is the class to take!

Dr. Cohen is one of the sweetest and kindest people you will ever meet, and you genuinely have to put no effort into this class to get an A. I don't think that means you learn nothing, it's just up to you to decide if you want to pay attention. He's a fascinating guy who can really teach you to love anthropology because he's SO passionate.

I have had Dr. Cohen in ANTHROP 3334 and this. He is my favorite professor. He helps anyone who is willing to work. He is intelligent, professional, and truly passionate. I loved being in his classes and I hope to take more of his classes! Our discussions make his classes some of the best in the anthropology dept. I recommend him to anyone in ANTHR

this class is extremely easy. Easy to the point where you are literally not being challenged to do anything but breathe in class. He always gets out of topic and wants to be your friend more than he wants to be your prof
Class is interesting and also very easy. You can tell hes super passionate about his research.

He is such a good man! His classes are very interesting and creative and he has many great stories, so you learn a lot. He is very caring and truly wants all his students to succeed. I truly love hearing him talk. He is always smiling and will talk to you after class. He deserves a free cruise and a lifetime supply of chocolate for his efforts.

Dr. Cohen is one of my favorite teachers that I have ever had at OSU. He's really nice, and know's a lot of cool information. His classes are also super easy, but even if they were difficult I would still take them, i've taken him for 3 classes, and will take him next spring again

Dr. Cohen, has so far been the best professor I've had in my college career. In some part because you can get an incredibly easy A, but also because of his character. Lectures could be boring at times, but his jokes kept me awake. As an anthropology major, he is a great person to talk to on insight on what to do after college with the major.
Show up to class and he literally gives you the answers. Easy 100%.

Jeffrey was awesome! I took his Zombie class and it was really easy, there are quizzes every class but he gives you the answers at the end of class and they are all in his powerpoints. You don't really need to go to class, but he's hilarious so I would go anyway. The final is just dressing up like a Zombie and writing a short paper about it

By far the best professor in the entire Anthropology department, I have taken 4 classes of his so far and he's the best. Makes class fun, makes you laugh ALOT, and best of all his classes are always super easy as long as you pay attention to lecture slides.

I did not like this man. He rubbed me wrong way. He made a few off the cuff comments that I found offensive. The Zombie class was supposed to be awesome, it ended up being my most dreaded class. I felt like most lectures were a far reach to the topic. The tests were very difficult. Each answer made scene and seemed like it could be correct.

Dr. Cohen is awful. He is zoo unbelievable unclear about even the simplest thing. He makes what could be a cool class solo boring and very difficult. I took a cultural elective and ended up getting a C because his tests are insane and not even logical. He is also mean and does not care to help student at all. I'M WARNING YOU, STAY AWAY FORM HIM

For Food Anthro Class: EXTREMELY EASY CLASS. Must attend lectures as class is small. Easiest class I've taken at this university. Cohen is funny--get to know him/on his good side, he tends to play favorites. His class is interesting and fun/laid back. Def recommend to anyone who likes food. Three tests, all typed and short answer.
XX
life changingly awesome

This guy is very enthusiastic about what he does and what he teaches, he always has a story to tell (in fact they're basically how he conveys his infinite knowledge).  As long as you read the books and show up to class you should get an A.  As previous students said, he can tell some pretty bad jokes, but you still appreciate his sense of humor.

Very helpful and knowledgable.  Tends to make a lot of bad jokes in class, but occasionally surprises us with a good one, and can hold my interest all the same.  A pretty easy grader too, so you don't need to worry too much about his quizzes and projects.

Dr. Cohen's enthusiasm and use of real life examples during lecture made this class interesting and enjoyable.  He was very clear about the material covered on his exams, and nothing was a surprise.  He was also understanding about redoing assignments for an improved grade.  A really nice guy and great professor!

I thought Dr. Cohen was extremely helpful and I feel as though I learned a lot from him. He gives real life examples; it is not just reading useless stuff and memorizing. You get to put your own insight and experience into your work. I def. would take a class with him again.

Great class—online and super easy. The professor is very understanding, and the due date for assignments is open until the end of the semester. Generally, it's 1 lab and a paragraph due a week. However, some weeks have an open note, multiple-choice quiz per module, or module poster. Overall, good, chill class.

Yerkes was very kind, caring, and had a great sense of humor. The class contained a 1–2-page paper every 2-3 weeks, a take home mid-term, and a final paper 4-5 pages. This class was very easy, he responded to emails quickly, and wanted his students to pass. His lectures were a bit longer, he was very understanding, cant say enough great things

Dr. Yerkes is a good professor. Sometimes his lectures are a bit boring, but otherwise teaches well. His assignments are opinion-based, graded on completion. The midterm was open note, take home directly from the lecture slides (very easy to get a 100%). Attendance is required, for the large assignments 15points is attendance during discussion day.

Prof. Yerkes rambles a lot during class, if you want to learn from him, it's beneficial to sit in the front of the class. The take home midterm was easy and all of his papers are graded easily as well. The papers are opinion based so you can't be wrong. He is a very nice person and I enjoy talking with him.

I took this class for a GE and it was one of the easiest classes I have ever taken. His lectures are pretty boring and you can barely hear him half the time but attendance is not mandatory. There are only a few very easy assignments throughout the entire semester and he grades very easy on them.

Took 1101 for a GE credit. Dr. Yerkes is a super understanding professor and is very reasonable with assignments and grading. The coursework is extremely manageable and the content is quite interesting.
Took 1101 first time it was offered. Easy yet interesting class. Perfect for Race and Gender Diversity GE

I took this class as a GE for my social science requirement. Lectures were kind of dry, though he means well and enjoys teaching. Exams were take home and open note, and you're given like 2 weeks to complete them. As long as you use the textbook and a few outside sources, the exams are not bad. Just be descriptive. Very passionate about the topic!

Lectures were tedious. There were copious amounts of reading assigned. Exams were take home, and homework assignments were pretty infrequent. Yerkes was clearly very knowledgeable and passionate about the subject.

Easy class, you don't need to come to get an A. Only on days you have things to turn in/or a presentation. He's really nice and a super easy grader. His lectures are a little dull but you don't even have to show up because he posts them online! There is however a lot of reading. Midterm and exams are take home too

This is the easiest class I've taken at OSU. Prof Yerkes is really nice and smart but his lectures are pretty long and boring and you can't hear him half the time. You use the book for 4 take home exams. He takes attendance every class and theres 4 in class assignments so its worth it to go but most of your learning will come from the book. Easy GE

His lectures are very dry but he does try his best to be engaging and is always prepared for class. His exams are not very difficult as long as you review his lecture notes that he posts on Carmen. Our assignments also were not very difficult as long as you put effort into them he will recognize that and grade you accordingly. Very passionate!

Just finishing up his Anthropology 1100 class. He posts the lecture slides on Carmen. He tends to ramble and holds the microphone unnecessarily close to his mouth... 4 take home exams, 4 easy in class activities, 1 in class final. Honestly, I didnt learn much from this class. If you want to actually benefit from class, take a different lecturer.

Prof Yerkes lectures from a word document every single say in class. He tends to ramble. Participation grade is based on attendance. 3 papers, 3 short assignments, 2 exams (1 take-home). I didn't learn much from this class but it was an easy A.

Dr. Yerkes is very quirky with a dry sense of humor that you learn to appreciate later in the semester. Two tests are both take home and the final is non cumulative. There is a debate, but it was is really easy. Him and the TA grade very generously, and there are 3 other small essays. Boring class, but easy.

This is hands down the worst class I have ever taken. It is supposed to be a discussion-based class, but he interrupts students constantly. He does not allow any bathroom or food breaks, even though it is an almost 3 hr class. He is rude and disrespectful of students' questions, time, and life outside of class. The class is boring and useless.

Lectures are not the most exciting thing you'll ever attend, but Dr. Yerkes has a great sense of humor and is a super cute little old man who is very intelligent.  He makes jokes a lot and is very friendly.  The class has a total of 3 assignments, one debate, a take home midterm, a single essay, and a take home final.  Definitely use your book.

Yerkes is a good professor. Has all his exams straight out of his PowerPoint. You need textbook for homework assignments though. Exams are easy if you study. Doesn't post grades online so you need to calculate and see where you at in class to get desired grade. Doesn't curve. Lectures were not mandatory and where boring.

Professor Yerkes is a great guy who is funny and easy to listen to. If you pay attention in class and take notes, and study the book the night before the exam, you should pass. None of the exams are cumulative, and they are not that bad besides. Showing up to class is probably the best part of the course because of his cool stories too.

Three midterm, non-cumulative exams. Very easy material . Either need to read book (vocab) or go to lecture. Both is not necessary. Boring lectures. Exams are extremely vocab-based. Has like 5 quizzes throughout semester. Doesn't post any grades on Carmen, so hard to keep track of your grades. Very nice and understanding guy.

Professor Yerkes is hilarious. He trails off into the most random subjects quite a bit, but when he's on topic, he knows what he's talking about. You will fail if you don't read the textbook. He's not very strict about attendance. And make sure you use every source he provides; he's very picky about that.

I would 100% take this again, the class is very easy and notes are posted. Tests were open note and open textbook and he is very passionate and knowledgeable about what he teaches. Class content was surprisingly interesting.

100% asynchronous course: well structured and straightforward, light workload, with a decent amount of writing. Some assignment types can be dropped, and the grading criteria are unambiguous. Also, he's a cool guy! I wish I had him for an in-person class, honestly.

Great professor! Overall really cares about students and your success. Easy weekly reflections on what you learned, and 3 papers on articles. 3 online exams that are on your own time (open book and notes). Take him!

Very patient and clearly loves what he is teaching. Easy to stay attentive in his class because of his enthusiasm and genuine concern. Weekly "what did you learn" assignment and 3 easy article reflections all semester. Not a harsh grader if you try and do what was asked. On exams, he gave very generous answers when you asked about a question.
Great Prof. Even though I have no interest in Anthropology, he still makes the class fun and entertaining. definitely take it if you need a bio credit.

I've never been very interested in anthropology myself, but Dr. Peterson did a great job keeping our class engaged and doing our best. His workload was pretty light, mainly just weekly labs, a couple short weekly discussion posts, and a handful of projects. He has a lot of cool experiences to share from his past fieldwork as well. I learned a lot.

Dr. Peterson is one of the nicest and most passionate professors I've had at OSU. He clearly loves what he does, which shows in his classes when he shares personal stories from his time in the field and gets students' thoughts on the topics he teaches. Attendance is only for lab days, but you'll definitely benefit from going to all the lectures.

Not really any extra credit but weekly assignments are so easy its like its extra credit. Attendance only mandatory on lab days. Prof is super enthusiastic about what he teaches. GREAT EASY class to fill natural science GE. Have to pay for the online lab but it was not too much $. Quizzes are open note. Clear grading criteria on the 4 easy projects
He loves his work so it makes the material interesting. No memorization required, projects are unique. You have to buy the book though because you use it for labs.

He was a new professor and I was a little skeptical about taking his class but I'm glad I did. Labs were somewhat difficult but graded easy. Instead of exams, we did projects and open-note section tests, which were also pretty easy. Listened to feedback we gave and it made lectures better. As long as you give a decent effort, should get an A.

Dr Peterson is a genuinely kind, caring, and intelligent teacher. He asks for feedback and actually makes changes based on student suggestions. Grades are based on projects, open note quizzes, lecture reflections, labs, and one group assignment. Make sure to submit online quizzes on time. Would definitely recommend this class

Professor Peterson is genuinely a caring and passionate teacher. He gets excited about the material and it makes him happy to see his students interested as well. He constantly asks for feedback from his students and it is obvious he adapts his teaching methods based on what we say in order to us learn better. 10/10, would recommend. He is amazing.
Exactly what you want from an online gen ed class. Highly recommend if you just want a chill class on your schedule.
New teacher who cared about the course material. Very easy A for anyone who needs honors credits :)

I personally loved this class! Whenever I brought him up to other students, he was lovingly called the "monkey professor". He'll talk about his research during class and it's genuinely interesting. His course work is quite easy, as long as you show up and pay attention during lecture, you'll get a good grade. Quizzes are open-note and pretty easy.

This guy just rambles on constantly each lecture, flying through the slides and not giving you enough time to write the terms down, not to mention there's like 10 new terms on each slide that he doesn't bother explaining.  There's only 3 grades (midterm, final, and an essay) and the tests DO NOT reflect the content we learned in class.

The professor himself is amazing, he is very kind and dedicated to his subject. I took this class for a GE requirement, and I don't think this was the class for me. The only grades that go in are a midterm, final, and research paper. I was frequently very stressed about this class.

Dr. Mckee is so set in his ways and refuses to think about how that affects his students. Your grade is based on 3 exams composed of intentional trick questions. Attendance is optional but if you don't go you won't pass. His lectures are disorganized, he just points at things, says the name, and doesn't answer questions. He is also downright rude.

Your grade depends on three exams.  Attendance is not mandatory however to do well on exams you have to come to lectures and take notes.  Lectures could be rather disorganized at times and he is not very good with technology.  He even sent our exam to the wrong class once.

Dr. McKee is SO cool. Hes such an interesting person and is just the sweetest guy. He cares about his students so much and has done so much interesting anthropology work throughout his life and has a lot of interesting stories. Also, the subject matter of his class is super interesting. Ill miss having him as a professor a lot.

This class is SO unorganized and hard to take notes for. He just points out things written on his pp, finishes class within 30 minutes, and then just gives 3 exams, and the tests are your only grade. He seems like a nice guy, but a terrible teacher who doesn't seem to ever know the answer to anyone's questions. I've had him twice now, both were bad

One of the best professors Ive had at OSU. Prof. McKee has so many interesting stories from his time in S Africa, which relate to the material. He is quirky, but I enjoyed his jokes. The class was pretty easy with tests being open book. Make sure you take detailed notes as most of the questions were from lecture. Labs are completion which is nice.
The only grades we received were tests and one paper. The professor didn't bother to communicate grades or feedback once we switched to online due to the pandemic in 2020. Lack of understanding.

Definitely go to class. Most of the material on exams is covered in the powerpoint. The powerpoint are not posted online and he doesn't use Carmen. I really like him as a person but not a great professor. He made a gen ed class so much harder than it should have been.

Genuinely one of the kindest people I have ever met. It is very clear he cares about the students in the class, and he enjoys teaching. He puts effort into being interesting and caring to his students, and is one of the most passionate instructors I have had at OSU. A real gen of a professor, I wish I could take him again.

McKee is the best professor I've had at main campus so far in personality. He is hilarious and will always make you laugh in his lectures. His exams are not too bad. They are multiple choice, short answer and essay usually. Just study and you'll be fine.
There are 3 exams for the entire class and a paper for extra credit. Hes super chill but lectures can feel a bit unorganized.
Lectures are very boring and unorganized. Tests were hard but if you study a lot you will pass. No textbook is used in class. He is nice and kinda funny.

Don't take this class. It's 1000x harder than the non-honors version. Professor McKee is extremely unorganized and doesn't even know his own syllabus. Exams are half multiple-choice/half essay and the essay portion is graded very harshly. There are three exams that basically decide your grade. He does not curve. He does not use Carmen.

THIS CLASS IS AWFUL. SO DISORGANIZED, TAKES OFF POINTS FOR ESSAYS ON EXAMS WITHOUT CLARIFICATION OF WHY. HORRIBLY MESSY LECTURES. never been so frustrated in a class. worst teacher I have ever taken at ohio state

The lectures are kind of dry and not the most interesting, however the labs are incredibly easy and there is no homework besides studying and a quick quiz before the labs. Professor McKee is clearly very knowledgeable and tells great stories about his anthropology adventures. The tests are pretty hard and are 67% of your grade.

Dr. McKee tells interesting stories about his experiences in South Africa, and the labs are participation graded and the pre lab quizzes are easy. His lectures are unorganized and hard to take notes on, and exams are over 60% of your grade with extended response questions. I found the exams fairly difficult, and you really have to study hard.

Solid choice if looking to fulfill a natural science GE - especially for people not into the hard sciences. Labs are really easy. Lectures are disorganized and unclear. He is passionate about his work and that shows but does not convey his knowledge effectively. There are three exams which you will need to study for. Will need to work for an A.

You must attend for the lectures in order to pass the exams. If you take good notes from the lectures and go to labs, you'll only need to study for 2-4 hours for the exams and get an A. He makes good jokes and has great stories related to the class from his fieldwork.

Prof. McKee is good. Not the easiest class (gotta work for the A), must attend every lecture because he doesn't put the slides online. Enthusiastic and extremely knowledgable about his coursework. Lot of memorization but it makes sense in the end.

The lectures were confusing and he is unable to clarify when asked questions. He is very unclear about what will be on exams. A lot of test questions are not covered in lecture. I was very disappointed with how this course was taught. Exams are short so each multiple choice question is worth a lot. (3 exams, 1 paper for 3% extra credit)

I really enjoyed having Prof Mckee for Anthrop 3300. He has funny stories and makes corny jokes and you can't help but laugh. Class attendance is a must if you want to do well on the exams. They're very detailed, but I was able to start studying 1 or 2 days before and get B's on them. I would definitely take another class taught by him!

Very interesting professor and a dad-like sense of humor. The class wasn't too hard, except he lectures heavily 3 days a week, so it's important to go because lecture notes are essentially the exam study guides, and power points don't go online. Besides studying for exams, all that's required for homework is an open note prelab each week.

He's definitely not the worst, but his easy-going lecture style doesn't match his difficult tests. I'd say don't let yourself become complacent just because he's so laid back in class. The textbook is not at all necessary.
Lectures are boring and does not clarify anything at all. Two mid-term and final exam.

Prof. McKee was a wonderful professor! His lectures were very clear and interesting, with fun narratives perforating large amounts of information. His tests weren't incredibly difficult, and I appreciated the fact that when he had extra time after lectures, he let students leave early. His sense of humor was personable and made me enjoy his class!

His lectures are really unorganized and the class has a lot of memorization involved. Labs are just graded for completion though which helped a lot. Exams were not super easy. You have to work for an A but its definitely attainable.

He may be very intelligent about physical anthro, but he's not a great teacher. His power points are bare, and his lectures are a bit hard to follow. The worst thing about this class is that he never bothered to put anything online, so if you miss a lecture, you have no chance of knowing what he taught that day.

This was my 2nd class with him, so he's not THAT bad. Tests are hard (start studying a couple days earlier than normal) and lectures are unorganized. He likes to tell stories and make corny jokes, which makes lectures a little less boring. No textbookother materials for this class, so everything he says is fair game for exams.

Jeff Mckee is a real cool guy with real world experience in Anthropology. His stories about his time in South Africa as a field anthropologist are great. His tests are pretty tough and you definitely have to study hard for themread the book. Every class is a lecture and his notes are not well organized. Labs are easy and you get 100% for complete

Great professor who has actually worked in his field and is very pasionate about the subject. Lectures can be boring but he makes little jokes here and there which are nice. Test may be difficult but you can tell that he tries to make them easy for us. Labs are super easy. Take this class.

I only took this class at first because it would fulfill my biological science lab requirement without requiring me to take a separate lab course. It was kinda dull, to be honest, but it was clear and Dr. McKee did his best to make things interesting. This class was good enough that I'm gonna take another anthropology course next semester.

He is one of the truly genuine teachers that wants to impart knowledge on students.  He is kind and understanding and will help you even if you have a difficult semester.  I enjoyed this class even though I was not originally interested in the content for Anthropology.  Thank you!

Dr. McKee knows what he's talking about but the info is really dry. I love human evolution and I have a hard time getting up for/staying awake during his class. He is a fun guy though and the tests are pretty easy. One paper that's technically optional but if you write it, you get extra points on your final.
Go to class, Jeff is a blast!

Interesting and and the guy knows his stuff. Class discussions were very good, and sometimes very funny ... he's easy to distract, but always brings the discussion back to the point.  People who complained about difficulty of tests are probably wimps who didn't study.  I found his questions  very relevant to the material he taught, and taught wel

Definately attend the lectures and write down as much as absolutely possible. He organizes them well and is clear. The BEST way to study is after EACH lecture! Do NOT wait until the last. Know the lectures VERY well; read the book to gel it. If you do that, you'll do EXCELLENT. don't be afraid! Anth. namedropper tho-little annoying hahah
Very interesting class.  McKee has interesting personal stories and really knows what he's teaching.  Don't blow off studying.

SOO hard. He expects us to know detail as if we've been studying anthropology for 30 years and earned 5 PhD's in anthro with extensive field research or something. And this is a 300 level class. I didnt think the material would be too bad, and it isnt. i remember a whole lot from this class, but the exams go into such pointless impossible detail
No Comments

Lucifer is disquised as a mild mannered professor. Lecture is actually interesting, but his exams are just downright evil!  Seemingly nice guy grades like he just wants to make you cry! Expects enormous detail. Beware!

Not an easy professor, he expects you to know details and is an extremely hard grader. His lectures are not bad, but they are not as helpful,since the test are ridicuosly detailed. If I had a chance to take it with somebody else, I would, without hesitation!

Dr. McKee is by no means an easy prof, but that's not always a bad thing.   He does expect details on exams, but the details that he wants are ones that you should expect to learn in a class about hominins--dates and dentition are fair game, and not unjustly so.  I'd definitely take another class from him if I had the time.

I went into this class expecting it to be very informational since this is an area of interest of mine. McKee is just bad. On the exam he will mark you off on your answers without saying why. It seems completely arbitrary and I was very unhappy with this professor.

Very interesting class.  Be sure you attend lectures and take lots of notes.  Review ALL notes before your exams.  The exams are TOUGH, just make sure you explain all your answers thoroughly...learning curve has to be quick with only 2 exams!  Big essay helps out the grade in the class and can cover any topic you choose.

Hard, I am an honors student, graduated highschool top of my class, and this class was completely pointless and he expected us to remember menial details that only an anthropologist workin for 50 years could remember. I got the lowest grade I have ever receieved in this class ever in my entire life. Beware.
He is very knowledgeable and interesting.  Well informed on current issues and is open to student input and ideas.  Always makes time for students!
Awesome professor.  Be aware that he hasn't found any hominin fossils yet and is a bit bitter about that.
Approachable, good lectures. Exams are more difficult than with most other instructors.

Dr. Trask's class is challenging, but engaging. Though the exams test your in-depth knowledge, Unstuck study proved to be a helpful tool for study prep alongside the textbook. Overall, a rewarding experience for anthro enthusiasts.

This professor cares for her students, easy to communicate. This course has weekly discussion post watch films, discuss it, respond to 2 peers. Written mid-term in-class, & final written online, study guide for both, there is also a group presentation (12 min minimum), and infographic at the end. There is a book, but don't need it to pass the class

This Professor is one you will remember, she is amazing and really cares. This class contains weekly discussion post watch films, discuss it, respond to 2 peers. Written mid-term in-class, a final written online, study guide for both, there also is a 12-page paper at the end of the class. The class isn't difficult if you try and complete the work.

She truly cares about her students welling being, wants everyone to succeed. Class contains weekly discussion post watch films, discuss it, respond to 2 peers. Multiple-choice mid-term in-class, a final multiple-choice online, study guide for both. Offers EX when students didn't go to class. Easy to reach through email and office hours

Dr. Trask is extremely knowledgeable and passionate in her lectures. She keeps the classroom interested and engaged due to this, and I never once felt afraid to ask for help. I do agree with other reviewers, though, because I could study for the midterm/final for hours and hours and still do poorly.

As an engineer I took this class as a GE like most people. Lexines appreciation for the subject shows, as she has a knowledge that is shocking in its array and depth. 

The class is very managable, ~biweekly homework which you should get a 100 with marginal effort. Exams are the lecture, go to class and it is not hard to get a pleasing grade.

Her class is very manageable and she also makes it very interesting. You only have one midterm and one final and the most amount of homework you get is two discussion posts a week. I would say study study study for the big tests because it may seem like you know enough about the class until you see your score lol.

I would not take a class with Dr. Trask again. Lots of readings and she speaks very slowly during lectures to the point that it's difficult to follow. Grades participation during class but only calls on a couple of people. She was very off putting and seemed like she didn't want to be there or interact with most students.

You can tell that she is very passionate about what she teaches and keeps you very interested in the course material. She can be a tough grader sometimes, but she does give a 2 day grace period on assignments if you really need it. Overall, if you show up to class everyday and do what she asks of you, it isn't hard to get an A in this course.

Dr. Trask is my favorite professor or teacher I've ever had. She always considers the student's mental health and is very lenient on deadlines. She deeply cares about all her students and genuinely wants them to succeed in class and life. The course can be challenging for someone new to Anthropology, but she will always take the extra time to help.
If you try to care about the material, you'll find that it is actually pretty interesting. I wouldn't expect to fall asleep in class and wake up with an A though.

Dr. Trask is a very intelligent person. I find that her lectures are stimulating and enjoyable, but she does require a lot of reading for this class specifically. All her courses have been a lot of work and required extensive studying and required attendance. I do not love the way she makes exams, but going to lectures helps you on the tests.

Dr. Trask is incredibly intelligent and knowledgeable. You can tell she is passionate about the topics she teaches. Takes attendance every lecture. Weekly homework and some discussions, but nothing difficult. The midterm is hard. The questions are very specific. Luckily there are a lot of other assignments to help boost grade.

Dr. Trask is super intelligent and knowledgable in her field and did an amazing job with the new 2210 class introduced to satisfy the GE credit. She was super helpful, always provided valuable advice, and made the class easy with active participation and listening. Would highly recommend her for Anthro2210!

as a nonanthropology major I was intimidated and thought I would do badly, but the requirements for assignments and exams are clear. I did much better than I was expecting. We read 2 novels for the class and I really enjoyed them. Definitely go to class because the discussion information is vital for exams. She is very willing to help her students

I've had Dr. Trask for about three classes now at Ohio State and she is absolutely my favorite professor I've had. She is passionate about her course material and presents the information in lectures that I find easy to follow. She is lenient with late work and provides a 48-hour grace on most assignments. I would recommend any course with her.

Dr. Trask is one of my favorite professors ever.  She is very knowledgeable about what she is teaching and creates lectures that are easy to follow and engage.  There are weekly reading assignments, but nothing is too lengthy.  You are expected two write two reflection papers, along with create and respond to weekly discussion posts.

This class was exceptionally difficult with all her questions being extremally specific and niche. I was one of the only people who did not bomb the midterms (average ~ 60%) and it took was rewatching and retaking notes for all her lectures for full days on end to get an A on them. Great prof if you love anthro, run if you don't.

Dr. Trask is very thorough and seems like a sweet woman, but I would not take her class again due to how difficult she made it. Everyone bombed the midterm due to how niche the questions were. Friends that took this class from other profs said it was super easy, but that wasn't the case here. I'd recommend a different professor if you can.

She is seriously amazing and changed my life. So passionate about meaningful subjects. Random but relevant tangents make it so interesting. Very knowledgable and grounded. Don't worry about doing bad, if you read the texts and participate you're in the clear. She's lenient with late work and understands we are human beings. Truly enlightening prof

Honestly one of the best professors I've had! She does have exams that are a tad bit difficult if you don't attend class regularly but she offered extra credit on them, outside of class review, and always answered questions! She genuinely cares about what she does and makes topics that may not be the most interesting as engaging as possible!

Dr. Trask was great! I learned a lot and the she really cares about her students. On days when attendance was low or if a lot of people in the class were having a rough week, she would reward us with free points! Just a heads up: she writes her exams in a way that tests if you *really* know the course material, so you are gonna have to study.

Dr. Trask is a very passionate professor who cares about her students. She gives weekly homework which consists of film worksheets and discussion posts. Her lectures are fill in the blank and she rarely posts her video lectures until the very end--so go to class. she also does tophat for attendance. only has 2 exams. questions are  kind of hard

If you are taking this class for an easy GE, take any other professor for this class besides this one! This professor is genuinely and utterly horrible and gives ridiculous amounts of work for a GE. The questions on the quizzes are either small details from the material or aren't presented clearly in the material. Also, homework during fall break.

I absolutely loved this course, and she is the best professor I have had (this is the second course I have taken with her and I plan on taking more if possible.) As long as you pay attention to the lectures, you should be good for the tests. There are a few assignments a week, but nothing too overwhelming. She is a very passionate professor!

Professor Trask is almost TOO accommodating... you have to be really committed to learning to have the self control to not half-ass the assignments due to how easy it is to get by without doing them. She is a lovely professor who made me feel comfortable asking any question to, never making me feel stupid for not knowing the answer.

I took her Into to Anthropology class and absolutely loved it. You should definitely attend the lectures if you want to get the most out of the material. However, she is very understanding and easy to work with if you cannot make class! Her exams are a little more on the tougher side, but as long as you take notes and pay attention youll do fine!

Great professor, she is kind and caring of her students. She is an easy professor to take for a future GE course. I would totally recommend her to anyone that needs a GE that is an easy A because her class is only based on discussion posts and exams. The exams are easy if you take notes and pay attention to class.

Dr. Trask was a great professor. She made the material and her assignments very interesting. But, since this class was asynchronous, it felt like I always had so much work to do. Be prepared to write a lot of discussion posts and short essays.

Dr. Trask is overall a great professor. I am currently taking her Anthro1100 and have really been enjoying the class. Each week is a different subdiscipline of anthropology so it keeps the class fresh. There are a decent amount of assignments each week but thats to be expected for an online asynchronous class. She keeps the lectures short as well!

Dr. Trask is a great prof. I had her for the Intro to Anthro class and genuinely enjoyed going to her lectures. She admits that her in person class is less work than her online class, so I would go with in person. She's very caring and understanding.

Easily one of the best professors I've ever had. Genuinely cares about her students, says things like "stay safe" over the weekend. Very understanding. I once forgot to do an assignment and she extended the deadline for me.

If you're taking an Anthro GE do it IN PERSON. This is my 2nd GE with Dr. Trask, & I found both to be fairly easy. Lectures are INTERESTING & much more thorough in class than online. Exams are open note, & she uses questions from the textbook (so rent it!). Great prof, caring, interesting, and hard working. Not too much HW for the in person section

Dr. Trask is knowledgable about anthropology, and it's pretty easy to get an A in her class. It is a lot of busy work, but it's manageable and appropriate considering it's a 3 credit hour class that's online. She's an easy grader and offers a decent amount of extra credit. She's exactly what you'd expect from a college professor.

I took this online as an easy GE, but it's not. You're supposed to read from the book, watch her YouTube lecture, watch a documentary every week and either take a quiz on it or write a summary and review. In addition, there is a workbook assignment, quiz, and 3 discussion posts every week. It's not terrible, but it's a lot of busy work for a GE.

has the most boring lectures ever and is a hard grader for a GE and Intro class. Take ANTHROP 2202 instead. 1100 is not hard, but theres a lot of busy work with discussions every Wednesday and quizzes and other comments due every Sunday with a film worksheet every Saturday. Readings are around 10-30 pages a week. She's also very unapproachable.

Beginning of the course, and this is an 1100 GE that is easy with every other professor, Lexine Trask said "I am going to make you work for this. A lot of you think an 1100 course will be easy, but not this one." So, that is upsetting to say the least. Funny at times, but just everything sucks. Average on an open notes syllabus quiz was a 7/10.

Trask really knows her stuff, but she never posts the lecture notes and if you miss them you're done for. Documentary worksheets and exams are ridiculously tough for an intro level GE course. Lab is super easy. Don't bother with the textbook- you'll probably never use it.

I barely read my textbook, and the test comes directly from the notes, so if you don't usually read textbooks, don't bother buying this one. There isn't much homework until after spring break, but even then, its bearable. She takes attendance on random days, but its best to go to class and takes notes anyways since she doesn't post slides online.
Dr. Trask is so passionate in what she is teaching. The course is very heavy on coursework and reading. If you apply yourself and do the work you'll get an A.

Dr. Trask is passionate about Anthropology and I admire that but be ready for a crap ton of work. Her class is demanding and her expectation is high. One could argue that should be expected but for a GE course its INTENSE. At first the material is fascinating but it gets exhausting with how much work is expected, that you'll lose interest quick.

I wouldn't recommend taking this course if you don't need it, or find another professor. Incredible amount of busy work and it is graded tough. There are so many insignificant things you have to go to get a good grade, and the lecture videos are impossible to watch. She is hard to talk to as she comes off as rude.

3 discussion posts, 30-60 minutes of lecture videos, 1-2 chapters of reading in textbook, sometimes other reading materials, 1-2 hour long videos with 15-25 question quiz or workbook assignment, 15-25 question quiz over readings/lecture every week. Horrible. Although, Lexine talks very slow so you can speed up the lecture videos to 1.25x or 1.5x

DO NOT take this class to finish your GEs. I am a graduating senior, and I spend hours on this course each week. I spend more time working on this course than my major classes, and am still sitting at a C (I'm an A student). The amount of work in this GE course is absolutely ridiculous, and assignments are unclear and complicated for no reason.

If you're looking for an easy class to fulfill your GE requirement - this is not for you. She is not specific in what she expects on the assignments and quizzes, she assigns hour long videos to watch every week with several assignments to do on top of that. I spend 3x as much time doing work for this class than my major classes.

DO NOT TAKE ONLINE ANTHRO 1100 TO FINISH YOUR GEs !!!! Or for that matter as a GE in general. I understand GEs aren't always a walk in the park but I have more weekly work in this class than I have ever had in any class ever. And it is all busy work, graded pretty tough, that takes time away from my major classes.

I did not expect how much work is required as weekly you have a 6-15 pg reading, hour long film , worksheet on the film, lecture video , workbook assignment on the reading & lecture video, a discussion, & a quiz. This seems like a lot but eventually you get adjusted it and enjoy the class. Just look at rubrics on carmen. she gives extra credit .
She is a great professor. Go to lecture in order to get attendance and extra credit points and for the most part they are interesting. The exams are very fair. Take her! Its a good GE.

She was very passionate in class about the material. She was also very understanding. I loved her. She gave lots of busy work to help your grade. Show up to class if you want non-graded brownie points.
For a GE, this class is way too hard. I am aware that classes shouldnt be a cake-walk, but this is excessive. I wanted to like Dr. Trask because she is a good teacher, just too difficult for a GE.

Brilliant woman, her midterm and final exam though are literally worth 50-60% of your grade. When you come to class and others don't, expect extra credit! Extremely lecture heavy, and on the first day she tells you she hates busy work. You'll have a film worksheet once a week, usually about an hour long documentary.... it's not challenging!!
I've taken Anthropology here with a lab and we didn't do half the work in this class. Took this so I could finish my GE's and have regretted it. Avoid this class.

This class is a ton of work. Expect to work on HW very regularly. A typical week includes reading a chapter of the textbook, watching an online lecture video, completing a lengthy written assignment, writing 3 posts in a discussion thread, watching 1-2 hour long documentary, writing about the documentary, and taking a weekly quiz.

This is a pretty lecture-heavy class, but Dr. Trask tries to present you with all the materials you need to do well. Anthro can be a bit hard if you don't care about taxonomy, but the worst part about this class is that it's at 8 AM. That said, I'd recommend Trask for this class if you need 2200H for GEs!
This class isn't easy and she expects you to know the material. But her lectures are interesting and class is pretty laid back. She love when you participate!

Had I taken a class of hers other than Theory I don't know how much I would have liked her. But she knows Theory is hard and few schools make it an undergrad requirement. And she told us she had a hard time learning it. So the class was designed for us to succeed. It wasn't easy but she she made it possible to get an A in the class.
She was fun to engage with and even though our lectures went on tangents they were relevant and she told us the truth always about the world and her opinion.

Really fascinating class, and she was always engaging to listen to despite some long lectures. She knows everything and more about anthropology. The book she assigns isn't really necessary, all the readings assigned in it are optional. Oh, and online examsreally easy class to pass. (most people got 95+ on the midterm)

Cultural anthro was an interesting course. Dr Trask is good about having class discussion, but it's a very lecture-focused class. She is somewhat opinionated and sometimes stubborn but she's funny and won't push anything on you. I describe Lexine Trask as an "intense mom" teacher.

This class in general is probably the hardest in the whole Anthropology department, and of course it's required but out of all the professor Lexine is clearly the best, she breaks down the tough material and helps you at any chance.

If you're looking for a GEC course that will have you pulling out your hair in frustration at times, this is the one to pick. Dr. Trask is a wonderful professor who does everything she can to educate her students and set them up to succeed: she's without a doubt been my favorite teacher. As long as you study your butt off, an A is a realistic goal.

NOT an easy GEC. I repeat NOT AN EASY GEC. Attendance is mandatory. Don't buy the book. Will get 100% on labs if you show up. She's a phenomenal professor that is passionate about the subject and she's funny which is nice because the material is painfully boring. Goes out of her way to help. Gives extra credit.

One of the best and coolest professors I've had in a while. She knows her stuff and is really funny. She wants her students to do well, so as long as you study, pay attention and do the online quizzes you'll be fine. I really hope to take another class of hers in the future.

one of the best professors I've had. I took anthro just to get a lab science GE and ended up falling in love with the subject. It isnt an easy GE and you definitely need to know the material front and back for the tests: she gives a lot of "a and b, all but c, c and d only, all of the above" type mult choice. Study hard but you can do well.
Really hard tests, but she explains everything super well and will help you with anything.  Will get 100% on labs if you show up.  Best prof I've ever had!

She is a great professor, very interesting and helpful, can tell she's knowledgable and passionate about the material. Class is labs and powerpoint notes, but the information is very detailed and the exams are difficult. No curve.

Lexine is da bomb, yo! Super interesting in class but still rockin' the technical science stuff (if you don't pay attention and take notes, you'll flunk out dope, so do dat yo!) But still totally an ace teacher. A+ double crank yo!

Dr. Trask is a FANTASTIC professor. She cares a lot about students and is passionate about the material. Exams are a little tricky but as long as you take great notes (more than the ones on the PPT) and pay attention, you should be fine.

I took the honors version of this class, and it was super easy. Only difference between this section and the regular is you have to do a group presentation-which you will get an A on no matter what. She gives you loads of opportunities for extra credit, and she's really passionate about the subject. If you need a sci GEC, this is the class to take.
Amazing teacher. Very invested in her students.

Easily one of my favorite instructors that I've had so far. Majority of grade was 3 exams but they are incredibly easy if you take good notes, show up to all of the lectures. She gave us extremely detailed review sheets for them as well. She also cut some of the BS out of lab which was great (especially considering the lab is stupid as is)

Great teacher. She did a wonderful job conveying information to students and had no qualms about taking questions or explaining something more than once. Only grades were two tests (midterm and final), which made getting a good grade difficult. However, she's a very good teacher, so don't let that stop you.

Lexine was the best prof I've had at OSU so far. She really knows her stuff, is very organized, genuinely wants to help, and can be really funny. Class is a little bit challenging and information-intense, and only grades are midterm and final, but she does all she can to prepare you. I would definitely recommend taking her class.

Trask is tough, but she's a great teacher and I thought the class was really interesting. It got me interested in anthropology, so that's a point in her favor. If you read what she assigns and pay attention, the exams really aren't that bad, and she's not that tough of a grader

GREAT TEACHER! I loved her and the class was interesting. She gives notes that you have to fill in the blanks. The book with articles is needed, the other one is not. Go to class and read the articles and the class is very easy!

One of the hardest classes I've taken - we're talking as bad as OChem, Biochem, Calc II, and Analytical Chem.  But... I now know my sh*t about theory.  Show up daily, occassionally say something, actively listen, follow her instructions to a t and you'll do fine.

Prof Trask is very helpful and manages to make a lot of the material more interesting than it should be but her tests are unfairly difficult and she doesn't curve them.  However if you actually go to class and make an effort to get to know her that will definitely improve your chances of a better grade.

Tests are very hard and she doesn't curve them even when the average in an honors class was a C-. A LOT of information and notes that don't really make sense overall.  She is really picky about essay answers.

Class is so detail-heavy and power points are so poorly organized that it's hard to decipher what is relevant.  Tests are extremely, unfairly hard.  People did poorly and she didn't curve the test, despite it being a fully attended honors class.
Fairly interesting class considering the subject but the exams are very difficult, she considers an average of 74% to be high....
Good teacher, but tests are very difficult and material can be dry at times.  Even for an Honors class I found it on the hard side. Perhaps if you enjoy Anthropology more it would be easier.

Prof Trask does have a high expectation from her students, but if you put in the effort an A is very possible. If you are having trouble she is more than helpful in answering questions and meeting with you. You will learn a lot from this class and if you keep at it, Prof Trask will reward your effort.

The problem I encountered was that often she expected you to read her mind (both in class and on assignments) the grading was a little insane and you were never sure what you did wrong even when you understood the readings (not just me, the class average was failing). She did seem to swing back and forth moodwise and get randomly angry at people
Very interesting and approachable.
i don't understand where this 2.0 average rating for easiness is coming from. Dr. Trask was very helpful and the class was really interesting, and it certainly wasn't a "2.0" level difficulty
One paper, one easy enough midterm, and one final. Small class size, interesting lectures. Easy GEC Social Science Course, and very interesting.

Pretty good professor. Managed to make a relativly boring class interesting because of her laid back attitude and good relationship with the students. Most people took the class simply as a GEC to avoid bio and had no interest in the class.  Prof Trask is a great lady who went out of her way to make sure every student had the opportunity to succeed

Don't listen to these people. Ya she might be a little hard on tests... but if ytou do the readings and study for 2 hours before each exam you will pass with an easy A. along with the extra credits for each exam and perfect attendance. Ur a lazy F*CK if you dont ace that class. WOOT WOOT to prof. trask

I'll be honest, I really didn't like her. I was so excited to take that class, and she really made me not want to attend. She is part of the reason why I left the Anthro department. I have only had one professor/ta in the Anthro dept I would say was a good instructor and that was Prof Cook. But he's not even around anymore, he left after 1-2 yrs.

Lexine was the WORST teacher I have ever had at OSU. I have never had issue with any other instructor during my four years in college. I BEG of you, do NOT take a class with her. She is rude and makes you feel that you are wrong simply because you don't agree with her opinion. AVOID HER CLASS!!!

Her class was fairly relaxed and easy going, however she is a harder grader and tests are not to be taken lightly.  I would also say I felt she plays favorites more than any other teacher I have had in college, so it is probably to your best advantage to go to office hours and have her get to know you.  At the same time, she seemed to hate suck-ups
The hardest and most stressful class that i ever took, but also one of my favorites because of the issues that were raised.  she taught me to be more globally conscious.
The class was very interesting.  Be careful on her essay exam!  It's harder then you think it will be but she is so fair about the way she grades.  Awesome class.
No Comments
She was very helpful to students, especially on the research paper.  She made the class interesting and really made you think about the subject material.  Very cool teacher.
Great instructor.  Very interested in getting to know the students.  Work hard on the term paper and presentation - it helps!!

Didn't really like the class and my major is archaeology. Very hard class for an intro course, but does give extra credit. She either likes you or she doesn't. Is probably excellent teacher in her own field of study.
Holds grudges against more advanced anthropology students in class. Not a good teacher.
Very willing to help.  Visit during office hours, it helps.  Lots of extra credit opportunity.
great teacher, lots of notes to study.  didnt really need to buy the book as long as you showed up to class.  cool teacher

Cool teacher....hard as hell, but is VERY willing to help.  VERY interested in wanting to get to know the student, so I STRONGLY suggest visiting her during office hours....Can really make a difference!!  Keep up with the readings, and the STUDYING!!

Hard class, but willing to help out if trouble!  Tests are some of the hardest I have ever taken! Definantly suggest if you need help, to see her, cause it will pay off in the end!  She likes students that visit her during office hours!!!
She was the best I ever had
Really opened me up to different cultures w/ such a sexy smile.The class is hard
Very nice and relaxed 11/10
Such a sweet lady and tries to make lectures interesting
I took both the lecture and the lab, it was my favorite class this semester. Graver is super kind and funny. She is super understanding and easy it is easy to ask her for help. 10/10 Recommend!!!

Took Professor Graver for both Forensic Anthropology and the Lab class. Even if you don't have any background in Anthropology, Professor Graver's knowledge and experience with the subject help make the class easy to understand. As long as you attend class regularly, you should be able to have a successful semester.

This is my third class with Professor Graver. I recommend her classes to most people I know in person. The classes are fairly straightforward. Show up, take notes and do the assignment, there's no tests in the lab classes and she's conscientious of student's time in all her classes.

attendance is only mandatory if you were in the lab. she was very carin, understanding, and nice especially when I came to grading. She has a cute little personality and you could tell she likes what she does.

Prof. Graver is an amazing professor to have (btw I'm writing this from Chabot). Her class is pretty easy because we have to pay attention to lectures which are entertaining because it's not a typical boring lecture and she talks about herself in them. Although she doesn't assign homework, we always have hands-on classwork to do at least each week.

The class was interesting and taught a lot of interesting details regarding anthropology. She wasn't strict or harsh she just taught well and gave helpful assignments and tests. A nice and easygoing professor with a likable personality.

Super nice and funny- loved her! Made the class interesting even when there were more boring topics like naming bones. Final project you get to do anything you want that's about the class which was cool. Easy class, easy assignments. It was like a nice break taking this class. Make sure to study for the bone tests tho! Def would retake her

Love Professor Graver most sweetest person ever!  Her class is really fun and interesting! We only did classwork no homework. She is really passionate about what she teaches. Classwork is pretty easy too! I wish she was my professor for all my classes. DEFINITELY recommend taking her class!

Professor Graver's anthro class is super chill and interesting. She gives great lectures and is obviously passionate about the material. The grade was based on quizzes (based on the lectures), the final (an "unessay", I did a presentation), and a couple other scattered assignments on the material. An A is very manageable. She is witty and cute.

I love Ms. Graver, a really down-to-earth teacher. She made me watch Game of Thrones and we share multiple interests in shows. She is a real sweetheart, and wish she was not my teacher, more so I wish I would have met her around the same age because she is quite stunning as well.
